DOC.HEAD: First Outbreaks of Flu Reported in Colorado, Minnesota
DOC.TEXT: The first outbreaks of the 1989-90 flu season have been reported in a Colorado day-care center and a Minnesota nursing home, the national Centers for Disease Control said. Twenty-four children in the day-care center became ill in November, and a test performed on one child found the influenza type researchers know as A-H3N2, one of the three major flu types, the CDC said Thursday. Then, during the week of Dec. 4, an outbreak began in the Minnesota nursing home, eventually spreading to four residents and two employees. A test found the same kind of influenza again. The CDC noted that all of the A-H3N2 influenza viruses it has tested this winter are the ``Shanghai'' flu, which the current flu vaccine protects against. In all, sporadic flu cases have been reported in 19 states. A few cases of a different strain of flu have been found. They resemble the ``Taiwan'' flu, which the vaccine also protects against. The CDC recommends flu vaccine, especially for people at increased risk of complications from influenza, including the elderly and those with heart or lung trouble.
